under.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: below or at a lower level than something, or covered by something
under.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Wendy had hidden the box under her bed.
We sailed under the Golden Gate Bridge.
Write your name under your picture.
I could see something glittering under the water.
He was wearing a jacket under his coat.
Under her arm, she carried a large portfolio.
In summer, we often slept under the stars.
I’d scare my mom by diving in and staying under  (=staying under the water) for as long as I could.
The bench collapsed under the weight of (=unable to support the weight of) so many people.
under.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: less than a particular number, amount, age, or price
under.translation[0].definitions[1].note: be under age (=be too young to legally drink, have sex etc)
under.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: These toys are not suitable for children under five.
Most of the events listed cost under £60.
I spend just under four hours a day seeing customers.
Children aged 12 or under must be accompanied by an adult.
under.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: used to say what is being done to something or how it is being dealt with
under.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Four new power stations are currently under construction.
The port was coming under attack from enemy warships.
The possibility of employing more staff is still under discussion  (=being discussed, considered etc).
All categories of expenditure are under review.
under.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: affected by a particular condition, influence, or situation
under.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: She’s been under a lot of pressure at work.
The operation was carried out while she was under general anaesthetic.
I’m glad to see that you have everything under control.
Two of our national parks are currently under threat from road schemes.
The doctor injected something into my arm and I immediately felt myself going under (=becoming unconscious).
He was accused of driving while under the influence of alcohol.
under the influence of alcohol/drink/drugs etc
under.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: according to a particular agreement, law etc
under.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: the question of whether the trade is illegal under international law
Under the terms of the agreement, the debt will be repaid over a 20-year period.
under.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: if something happens under a particular leader, government etc, it happens when they are in power
under.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: a program initiated under President Clinton and continued under President Bush
Under her leadership, the magazine’s circulation doubled in less than a year.
Would it have been different under a Labour government?
under.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: if you work under someone, they have a higher position in the company, organization etc than you, and they help to direct your work
under.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: She had a total staff of ten working under her.
From 1847 to 1851 he served under Captain John Randolph Stokes.
At Cambridge he studied under  (=was a student of) F. R. Leavis.
under.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: used to say in which part of a book, list, or system particular information can be found
under.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: The baby’s records are filed under the mother’s last name.
under.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: if you write or do something under a particular name, you do it using that name instead of your real name
under.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: He made a few records under the name of Joe Ritchie.
under.translation[0].note_box[0].section: something that is under something else has that thing directly above it or covering it
The pen was under the desk.
She had a T-shirt on under her sweater.
in a lower position than something else, though not always directly under it
From the cliffs we could barely see the people on the beach below us.
His apartment is below ours on the left.
under – used especially to emphasize that something covers, touches, or hides something
The girls wear shorts underneath their cheerleading skirts.
I found the book underneath the sofa.
under or at a lower level
They strolled hand in hand beneath the summer moon.
The water lies just beneath the surface of the earth.
under.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: less of an action or quality than is correct, needed, or desired
under.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: an underpass  (=a road or path that goes under another road)
under.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: less important or lower in rank
under.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: a head gardener and three under-gardeners
